feed.subtitle: An article and a computer model to help you understand life on a spinning space station

entry.title: Outside links and references
entry.content:
Gravity through spinning provides an interesting topic for study because it is so different from our everyday experience. The Coriolis effect is an unexpected byproduct of a spinning world.

Another Coriolis model

This website contains another interesting Coriolis model. Here, Andy Giger’s computer model takes another look at the Coriolis effect with spinning water jets. As you can see in his model, the water veers forward, into the direction of rotation. If you look carefully, you will see that every dot of water follows a perfectly straight line, but collectively it looks like a curve.

The Enterprise

The right hand rule for cross products


My experience with physics

I would quickly like to note my experience with physics. I do not have a physics degree, but I have studied physics-mechanics three times in school. I was successful each time. Physics fascinates me!

I originally studied physics as a high school student. The next year, I studied physics again as an advanced placement student.

In college, I ended up taking this course a third time due to some school requirements. I took “Principles of Physics I, for Scientists and Engineers.” I earned an A.

In none of these classes was the Coriolis effect ever mentioned. I was never given a physics problem similar to this one. It seems too complicated for an exam. I cannot remember where I originally read about the Coriolis effect. This subject is something that has fascinated me for years.

entry.title: Artificial gravity in science fiction
entry.content:
Artificial gravity in science fiction

Artificial gravity has never been used in space, so our current perspective comes from science fiction. Sci-fi movies are not realistic; a “real” picture is not cinematic and would be difficult to simulate. No space movie has ever depicted the Coriolis effect.

In many sci-fi movies, you see an artificial gravity “generator” underneath the station that uses an energy source to produce pure gravity. This is impossible!

Some movies have taken a more “realistic” approach to sci-fi, showing rotating space stations. I will discuss some of these stories below. There are many options to choose from.

Sci-fi films with rotating spacecraft

Here is a short list of sci-fi films with rotating spacecraft, and the names of those spacecraft:

  • 2001: A Space Odyssey (1968): Spacecraft Discovery One

  • Ender’s Game (2013): Battle School

  • Interstellar (2014): Endurance

  • The Martian (2015): Hermes

  • Passengers (2016): the Avalon

Even in films that take a more realistic approach, there are some mistakes in their gravity simulations. Here are a few examples.

The Avalon

In Passengers, the entire story takes place aboard a rotating spacecraft, the Avalon. Passengers travel for many years to emigrate to another star system. In this movie, you see correctly that a ride on the elevator could temporarily cause 0g. One mistake is that a failure in the gravity drive would not cause gravity to “stop” abruptly; the station’s rotational momentum would prevent that.

Try it!

Diameter=500 m

Start height=4 m

Angle=0°

Speed=0 m/s

Gravity=100%

This button shows you how the waterfall in the main concourse of the Avalon should appear.

Ender’s Game is a fantasy story, but the main plot is about artificial gravity and weightlessness. Ender is trained to fight weightless space battles in a zero-g “battle room.” In this “battle room,” every action Ender takes depends on his direction. This would also be true in artificial gravity due to the Coriolis effect. One missing gravity detail is that the hallway into the battle room would be almost zero-g. Gravity would vary based on how far you are from the center of rotation.

Try it!

Diameter=2640 ft

Start height=4 ft

Angle=90°

Speed=20 ft/s

Gravity=100%

In battle school, if Ender were to toss an object 10 feet away in his room, it would land about 1½ feet off-target (assuming a half-mile diameter).

It seems clear that an accurate spacecraft story requires a physics expert. We simply do not have experience with such things to know clearly what it would be like.

entry.title: The math behind this model
entry.content:
The math behind this model: “difference from throw on Earth”

As I began putting this computer model together, I wanted a simple go-to measurement for the difference between a rotating throw and a throw on Earth. This provided me a fascinating physics problem. My goal was to calculate, if a person were to toss a coin in a rotating environment, how far away would it land from their feet?

Set up the problem

To fully understand what happens during our coin toss, we must use a perspective that is not rotating. When beginning to solve a physics problem, it is important to establish a coordinate system. This helps to make sense of what is going on.

The station is a virtual coordinate system with (0,0) at its exact center and the thrower at the very bottom. I imagined the station rotating clockwise.

Here are some conditions for this coin toss:

  • At the moment of the throw, the person is standing at the bottom of the circle, at 270 degrees or 3π/2 radians.
  • The person is holding the coin at 4 feet from the floor. This is the starting height.
  • The person throws the coin straight upward at 14 ft/s, which would have sent the coin about 3 feet up in the air on Earth.
  • The rotating space station has a diameter of 50 feet. It is rotating at the speed necessary to produce 1g of acceleration, or 100% Earth gravity at the floor.
  • The coin experiences less than this amount of centripetal acceleration or “gravity” because it is not at the floor.

The next picture is a diagram of the velocity components for the throw. Before the throw, the coin has a leftwards velocity ($V_x$) due to the clockwise rotation; the object also experiences the centripetal force upwards ($F_c$). The throw adds an upwards velocity of 14 ft/s (the throw speed); the centripetal force ceases. The velocity components define the overall direction that the coin travels through the air ($V$), which we will need to calculate so we can determine where it lands.

Steps to solve the problem

Now that I have set up the problem, I will explain the next steps. Ideally, I would like a single equation that can solve the problem for me. Unfortunately, such an equation would be messy and impossible to simplify, so we will solve this in steps. We want to find how far away a coin would land from the thrower’s feet. To find this, we need to find the coordinates of where both the thrower and the coin would end up.

First, we need the magnitude and direction of the coin’s velocity after it launches. Using this, we can solve for its landing coordinate and the time it elapsed in the air. We can then use the time elapsed in the air to find where the thrower would end up in an equivalent time period. We can use this to find the separation between the coin and the thrower’s feet.

Here are the steps to solving our math problem:

  1. Calculate the magnitude and direction of the coin’s velocity through the air
  2. Find the coin’s landing coordinates
  3. Calculate the time elapsed as the coin traveled through the air
  4. Calculate the arc swept by the thrower during this same time
  5. Calculate the thrower’s final coordinates
  6. Calculate the distance between the thrower’s feet and the coin where it lands


Starting velocity

We need the vertical and horizontal velocity components of the coin. The vertical velocity has been given to us as 14 ft/s, the throw speed. The horizontal velocity is currently unknown, but it is based on the speed it was rotating before the throw. Using this information, we can calculate which direction the coin is moving.

Before we solve for the coin’s initial horizontal velocity, please note that the coin does not feel the same force of “gravity” as the person’s feet do on the floor of the station. Its distance to the station’s center is smaller than the station’s radius because you are holding it in your hand. The coin starts at a height of 4 ft from the floor. Thus, the coin’s horizontal velocity would not be quite the same as if it were touching the floor.

We can calculate the coin’s velocity using the equations for centripetal acceleration, which produces the station’s “gravity”. Here is our equation:

Variables:

  • a is the acceleration (in ft/s/s) felt at a given radius on a rotating object
  • $v$ is the horizontal (tangential) velocity at this radius in ft/s
  • r is the radius, or distance to the center of rotation in feet

Unfortunately, we do not know either the acceleration felt by the coin or its current horizontal velocity. We will have to calculate it based on the station’s rotation rate, which we can get from the floor, where the acceleration is 1g. The rotational speed in radians per second will be equivalent at the floor and at the coin.

Rotational, or angular, velocity (rate of spin) is related to linear velocity (straight-line motion). This relationship is defined by $v=\omega*r$ where $\omega$ is the rotational rate of the station in radians/second.

We can use this with our centripetal acceleration equation to get rate of rotation at the floor by replacing $v^2$ with $\omega^2*r^2$. This gives us:

Rearrange:

In this formula:

  • $a=-32.174$ ft/s/s (1g), the acceleration at the floor
  • $r$ is the radius of the station, or 25 feet.
  • $\omega$ is the rotational speed in radians per second. It is negative because the station is rotating clockwise.

Now that we have the rate of rotation, we can calculate the horizontal velocity of the coin. The radius at the coin will be 25 ft minus 4 ft, or 21 feet. The velocity will be negative because the coin is traveling left.

If you put all of this together coin using $v=\omega*r$, using the rotation rate from the floor and the radius at the coin, you get:

Our variables:

  • $v_x$: the horizontal velocity of the coin, which we are calculating
  • a: the acceleration of the station, -32.174 ft/s/s
  • $r_{s}$: the radius of the station, 25 feet
  • $h_{c}$: the starting height of the coin, 4 feet

$v_x$ works out to -23.82329$ ft/s.


The coin’s landing coordinates

We can use the velocity components of the coin to find its landing coordinates. The coin is traveling up and to the left in a straight line; the slope of the path it follows is the fraction of the two velocity components, $\frac{v_y}{v_x}$. The landing coordinates will be where this line intersects with the station, a circle.

The equation for our line in slope-intercept form: $y = mx - r_c$

Our variables:

  • $m$: the slope, or $\frac{v_y}{v_x}$. It will be negative because the coin is moving left and up.
  • $r_c$: the y-intercept. This is the radius where the coin starts, mapped to our coordinate system. This is subtracted because it is below the center.

Given that $v_x=-23.82329$ ft/s, $v_y=14$ ft/s, and $r_c=25-4=21$ ft, this is the line that makes up the coin’s path:

Now, we need to find where this line intersects with the circle that is the station. Here is our formula for the circle:

  • Note: $r_s$ is the radius of the station.

We can cheat for a moment and solve for our coordinates using an online graphing website:

In this image, you can see the path of the coin and its final intersection with the floor on the left. The coin starts at the y-intercept; everything to the right of that is irrelevant. The numbers in this picture will help us validate our answers later.

Now, we will develop a formula to solve for the x coordinate. The computer model needs a formula! I am leaving $\frac{v_y}{v_x}$ as the variable $m$ for simplicity’s sake.

Here are our equations again:

Put them together:

Next, rearrange and simplify to a quadratic equation (format $0=ax^2+bx+c$) by multiplying the y term and combining like terms:

The quadratic formula:

Plug in our variables and simplify:

This is our formula for the x-coordinate of the coin. The operator we use depends on what quadrant the coin lands in; in other words, it depends on the conditions of the throw. In this problem, the correct value will be the answer that is negative because the coin goes to the left. The equation correctly gives us -24.036 when we solve with the (-) operator.

Now we need to solve for the y-component that matches this x-component. Here is the equation for our line again:

Inserting -.587660 for $m$ and 21 for $r_c$ gives us an answer of y=-6.875. The coin’s final coordinates are (-24.036, -6.875).

Once more, here are our final formulas for the coin’s landing coordinates:

Our variables:

  • $m=\frac {v_y}{v_x}$. Both $v_x$ and $m$ are negative because the coin is moving left.
  • $r_{c}$ is the radius where the coin starts, or the y-intercept.
  • $r_{s}$ is the radius of the station.


Time Elapsed

Now that we have the coin’s landing coordinates, we can solve for the exact time elapsed using kinematics. To calculate this, we need the distance traveled; however, we only need this in one dimension. We will use the initial and final x-coordinates. The coin travels from 0 to $x_f$, and its velocity is $v_x$.

Basic kinematics tells us that $d=vt$ for objects that are not accelerating. We can rearrange this and plug in our values. We get:

Our variables:

  • $t$ = the time elapsed
  • $x_f$ = the final x-coordinate of the coin
  • $v_x$ = the velocity x-component

This solves to almost exactly one second, or 1.009s.


The Arc Swept By the Person

We can use the time variable to calculate the angle a person will rotate while the coin is in the air. This will give us the final coordinates of the person.

We have already calculated the station’s rotation rate in the beginning of our problem. This is $\omega$, in radians/second, and this is negative because the station is moving clockwise (counterclockwise is positive). Remember, $\omega=-t*\sqrt{\frac{a}{r}}$.

If $\theta_p$ is the total arc swept by the person, then you would expect $\theta_p=\theta_f-\theta_0$, the final minus the initial angles. The person starts at an angle of $\frac{3\pi}{2}$ (270 degrees). The person is also sweeping a negative arc.

With rotational kinematics, we can calculate this arc swept by the person:

Put the equations together:

Rearrange:

We can also think of this in terms of the station’s acceleration:

We have just calculated the person’s final angle in the station. Now, we have a set of polar coordinates: we have the final angle and the radius. We can convert these polar coordinates to cartesian coordinates using the equations:

Our final equations for the person’s x and y coordinates:

Our variables:

  • $r_s$ = the radius of the station
  • $a$ = the rotational acceleration, which equals earth gravity (32.174 ft/s/s)
  • t = the time elapsed while the coin is in the air

The person’s final coordinates are (-22.763, -10.336).


The Final Answer

Now that we have both the landing coordinates of the coin and the person’s final coordinates, we can calculate the straight line distance between the two using the Pythagorean theorem. This formula gives us our answer:

  • $x_c$ and $y_c$ are the coin’s final coordinates
  • $x_p$ and $y_p$ are the person’s final coordinates

This tells us that the coin landed 3.687 feet away from the person’s feet.

The model then breaks up the path of the coin into 100 pieces, reorients each of these points to the person’s perspective at that moment, and moves real-time between these points to make an arc on the screen.

The Coriolis force in the moment of the toss

Let’s look again at the same toss calculated above, but only at the moment the object is thrown. It is possible to calculate the direction and magnitude of the Coriolis “force” that a spinning object feels in a precise moment.

This section would not be useful for the distance calculation above because the direction of the Coriolis force would constantly be changing. Nonetheless, this can help us understand in which direction an object’s path is being distorted.

This article provides an equation to calculate the Coriolis force in a given moment:

  • $F_C$ represents the Coriolis force felt by a spinning object
  • m is the mass of the object
  • $\Omega$ is the rotational velocity expressed as a vector (pointing in the direction of the axis of rotation)
  • v is the object’s velocity expressed as a vector

This equation is a cross product. I do not intend to fully calculate this right now, but even without calculations, we can use simple logic to understand the direction of the Coriolis force.

The Right Hand Rule for Cross Products

When calculating a cross product like this one, you can use your right hand to figure out where cross product’s answer will point. The pointer finger points along the axis of rotation; since my space station rotates clockwise, the pointer finger would point forward. The middle finger points in the direction the object is moving; the object is moving upward. The thumb, then, points in the opposite direction of the Coriolis force since the equation has a negative sign (to account for this negative sign you could just use the left hand instead). The Coriolis force would point leftward, or toward the rotation. This matches the result on the computer model; the tossed object initially curves left.

Here is a summary of the forces a spinning person would see:

  • Objects moving with the rotation would appear to move downward because they are effectively rotating more quickly.

  • Objects moving opposite the rotation would seem lighter and would move “up.” If you matched the station’s speed, you would become weightless because you are no longer spinning.

  • Objects moving “upward” would appear to be pushed in the same direction as the rotation.

  • Objects moving “downward” would appear to be pushed opposite the rotation.

  • Objects moving along the axis of rotation would not be affected. The Coriolis force only affects motion perpendicular to the axis of rotation.

The Coriolis force is also called a pseudoforce because it only seems real to someone who is rotating.

Conclusion

It takes complex calculations just to understand a simple motion in a spinning environment; thus, it seems to me that Coriolis effects and forces are best understood with computer models.

entry.title: Rotation research regarding nausea
entry.content:
Most of the information on this page has been drawn from this link.

Rotation research regarding nausea

Living in a centrifuge may be nauseating and difficult to get used to.

Minimizing a space station’s rotation rate would reduce the nausea astronauts experience. We can reduce the revolutions per minute (rpm) required to produce 1g by increasing the station size; however, it is unclear what rotation rate would be desirable, and large stations would be expensive. When we finally build a spinning space station, we should experiment with several rotation rates.

Are you dizzy yet?

Unlike astronauts entering zero gravity, rotating astronauts must adapt to more than one sensation. While rotating, each direction of motion produces a different effect on the inner ear. This means that individuals would need to adjust to both the rotation itself and to sudden changes in direction. Windows might also be disorienting on a rotating space station.

Nausea research on Earth began in 1958 in the Slow Rotating Room, a facility in Pensacola, Florida. NASA placed individuals in a rotating room for several days.

NASA's Slow Rotating Room

The Slow Rotating Room generated some important findings. Study participants quickly learned to restrict their head movements, otherwise they would feel sharp nausea reactions (“acute nausea”). Over time, these individuals adjusted and became less restricted.

This page explains: “Although few adverse effects are present when rotation rate is less than 1 rpm, higher rates produce motion sickness (similar to that occurring during the acute period of adaptation to weightlessness).” Researchers found that their test subjects could adapt to 3 rpm.

Try it!

Diameter=200 m

Start height=1.2 m

Angle=0°

Speed=4 m/s

Gravity=100%

A space station would need to be 200 meters to produce 3 rpm at full gravity. The International Space Station is 109 meters wide by comparison. Press this button to see a coin toss emulated on a 200-meter space station (the coin lands 20 cm away).

Higher rotation rates would be more difficult to adapt to. In 10 rpm, individuals showed no adaptation after 12 days. The study indicated it is possible to build up to this rate in small increments, about 1-2 rpm per day; this might be an impractically long adjustment. My model’s default settings display a station at about 11 rpm (the speed for 1g with a diameter of 50 feet).

It is unclear how significant these studies are. A centrifuge in outer space would rotate you vertically, not horizontally.

A 1993 study in Udine, Italy focused on vertical rotation in a bicycle-powered centrifuge. Participants were able to move their heads without acute motion sickness at rates up to 19-21 rpm. Unlike the Slow Rotating Room, this study did not expose participants over several days; this would be very difficult.

It is not clear how well our bodies would adapt to rotation in space.

Construction strategies to prevent nausea

There are a few strategies that could be helpful for reducing nausea when building a rotating space station.

Try it!

Diameter=50 ft

Start height=4 ft

Angle=0°

Speed=14 ft/s

Gravity=33%

  • We could build a space station that produces less than 1g. This would not need to rotate as quickly, and it might produce some positive health benefits.
Try it!

Diameter=50 ft

Start height=4 ft

Angle=0°

Speed=14 ft/s

Gravity=200%

  • Studies have indicated that intermittent gravity is helpful. Would a higher rotation rate be tolerable if it is only for an hour a day? Try the coin toss in 2g!

  • It is possible to simulate gravity by rotating two capsules connected by a tether. With this strategy, we could build a spinning environment with an arbitrarily large radius, allowing us to reduce the spin rate. The astronauts in Gemini 11 briefly studied this phenomenon. This strategy may prove less expensive than building an enormous station, though the tether may require exceptionally strong materials.

  • A modular station could be expanded over time, allowing us to reduce the rpm requirements or increase the gravity capability. Gravity would be highest at the ends and lowest in the middle.

Reducing the spin rate would also reduce the Coriolis effect, another desirable outcome.

entry.title: The history of research on rotation in outer space

link.title: The history of research on rotation in outer space

entry.content:
Most of the information on this page has been drawn from this link.

The history of research on rotation in outer space

Artificial gravity from spinning has been popularized by science fiction; this is where our perception of it comes from. In the real world, a spinning space station has never built, and no space agency has active plans to build one; nonetheless, NASA’s archives are littered with proposals for one. It is interesting to take a break from fiction and see what real efforts have been made to learn more about spinning in outer space.

Organizations like NASA and Roscomos (the Russian space agency) have been working feverishly to try to make life in space viable. Space agencies may eventually choose to construct spinning artificial gravity habitats to solve the health problems of weightlesness.

Here is some of the history of spinning in outer space:

  • The Gemini 8 mission (March 1966) accidentally produced 4 g’s after a thruster incorrectly fired. The fast rotation caused intense nausea, and the astronauts nearly blacked out from the g-forces. The mission was aborted.
Gemini 11
  • The Gemini 11 mission (September 1966) purposely rotated two capsules connected by a 36-meter tether to produce 0.0005 g. The astronauts did not feel the gravitational force (the perception threshold is about 0.2 g), but they observed objects slowly floating toward the floor of their capsule. They reported it had been “an interesting and puzzling experience.”
Try it!

Diameter=45 m

Start height=1.2 m

Angle=0°

Speed=0 m/s

Gravity=.05%

Press this green button to emulate the gravity of the Gemini 11 mission. It takes 23 seconds for an object to land after dropping it.

  • In 1973, NASA’s only concern with zero gravity was motion sickness, which was only a problem for the first few days in orbit. This was the NASA flight surgeon’s position: “The magnitude of the motion-sickness problem experienced by astronauts to date does not appear to suggest clearly the need for design and incorporation of artificial gravity system in near-future space vehicles.”
Kosmos 782

  • The Soviet space program was initially very interested in artificial gravity in space. As early as 1961, the Soviets began studying how animals responded to various g-forces in parabolic flight (flights that do not reach orbit).

  • In 1975, on Kosmos 782, the Soviets centrifuged animals in space. Fish and turtles were centrifuged at 1 g for 20-days in a 75 cm diameter centrifuge. The researchers did not find any differences between either the centrifuged animals, animals housed in 0g, or Earth-bound animals.

Skylab

  • The American crews on Skylab took advantage of the large open compartment and ran around the curved circumference. Running in a circle created gravity. They reported no difficulty with either locomotion or motion sickness.

  • The negative effects of weightlessness became clearer during long-duration missions on Russian space stations such as Mir.

  • Several studies on Earth have looked at long-term bed rest, which produces similar health effects to zero gravity. A 1998 study in Tokyo found that one hour a day in a centrifuge prevents blood volume from dropping in a bed rester and maintains the blood-pressure reflex. In 2005, NASA conducted similar studies in their Short-Radius Centrifuge in Houston.

Off-axis rotator

  • In 1998, the European Space Agency built an “off-axis rotator” for the ISS. This device centrifuged humans for seven minutes at a time at several speeds. Subjects said they felt like they were standing on their heads.

  • In December 2014, NASA launched a fruit-fly centrifuge to study the effects of artificial gravity on the immune system.

The scientific community periodically comes up with new gravity ideas, though we will never fully understand life in a spinning environment until we create an environment for outer space.

Actual Spacecraft Proposals

  • In 2011, NASA proposed the rotating Nautilus-X as a possible stopover for astronauts embarking on long-distance missions; it might be relatively inexpensive and feasible (~$3bn). It seems likely that we will build something similar to this first.
Nautilus-X (proposed)
  • The next picture is an interesting example of an early study into spinning space stations. The 1969 design below requires a few revisions to work. The center corridor would need to be an elevator or a ladder. Also, you would be unable to stand in the long cylindrical containers; they are oriented in the wrong direction.
1969
  • This next image is for the Rotating Mars spacecraft, a 1989 concept idea. A space station using this tethered method could have an arbitrarily large diameter. An especially large space station at 1g may require exceptionally strong tethers using future materials such as carbon nanotubes.
1989
  • In 1975, NASA designed a massive theoretical ring station, a “Stanford torus,” as a thought experiment. The Stanford torus has a proposed diameter of 1800 meters (1.1 miles), the minimum size to produce 1 rpm with full gravity. Here is an interesting news story about it.
The Stanford torus
Try it!

Diameter=1800 m

Start height=1.2 m

Angle=0°

Speed=4 m/s

Gravity=100%

Press this button to see a coin toss emulated on the Stanford Torus. The coin toss lands 8 cm (3 in) away. Perhaps someday we will reach out to the stars with a station like this one.

entry.content:
Fun things to do with the computer model

Here are some things you can do with the model.

Try it!

Diameter=50 ft

Start height=4 ft

Angle=0°

Speed=0 ft/s

Gravity=100%

  • Try dropping the coin instead of throwing it (throw it at 0 ft/s). It curves in the opposite direction.

  • Next, try dropping the coin from almost the center of the station. With the diameter at 50 feet, place the starting height at 24.5 feet. Imagine you are standing on a tall pole and drop the coin while rotating near the center. It appears to spiral outward slowly due to the low gravity near the center. The coin actually travels in a straight path, but the floor–where we are observing from–rotates relative to the coin.

Try it!

Angle=0°

Speed=0 ft/s

Angle=0°

  • Now try dropping it at the exact center of the station (25.0 feet). The coin will never land!
Try it!

Diameter=50 ft

Start height=4 ft

Angle=0°

Speed=14 ft/s

Gravity=10%

  • Set the gravity to 10%. As you would expect, throws in low gravity do not appear as they would on Earth.
Try it!

Diameter=50 ft

Start height=4 ft

Angle=25°

Speed=14 ft/s

Gravity=100%

  • Try experimenting with the angle of the throw. Positive degrees are to the “right”, and negative degrees are to the “left”. At 25 degrees (14 ft/s, start at 4 ft), the coin loops back on itself.
Loop, at 25°
Point, at 36°
Try it!

Diameter=50 ft

Start height=4 ft

Angle=90°

Speed=14 ft/s

Gravity=100%

  • Try throwing the coin exactly opposite the rotation by setting the angle to 90 degrees from vertical. You are counteracting the gravity on the coin by slowing it down. The throw stretches out impressively far!
Try it!

Diameter=50 ft

Start height=4 ft

Angle=90°

Speed=23.823 ft/s

Gravity=100%

  • Increase the throw velocity to exactly match the speed the coin had before the throw, which you can find in the output menu (23.823 ft/s on default settings). Leave the throw angle at 90 degrees from vertical. You have stopped the coin midair! The model does not render the throw because the coin never lands. The coin would float in a perpetual circle.

  • Decrease the throw velocity very slightly (by 1/100 ft/s) so you no longer match the coin’s speed exactly. The coin hovers in midair, floating in circles relative to the thrower. It slowly lands after 17 minutes (1020 seconds), although this is unrealistic because there would be air currents.

Try it!

Diameter=50 ft

Start height=4 ft

Angle=90°

Speed=23.81 ft/s

Gravity=100%

Hovering midair
  • Exactly match the coin’s speed again. Now decrease the throw angle by one degree (to 89 degrees), so it launches one degree up from horizontal. It slowly spirals upward toward the center, at which point it reverses direction and spirals back down to the floor!

Speed=150 ft/s

Gravity=100%

  • Throw the coin up super high by increasing the throwing speed. At a high speed, it curves to the ceiling.

Let’s create a massive rotating firing range with a diameter of 10,000 km. As you increase the size of a station, in theory, the error due to the Coriolis effect decreases. This section will show you that even the most massive space stations have visible error due to the Coriolis effect.

We will try cruise missiles and bullets at both long-range and short-range. A bullet’s speed is close to the speed of the floor, which means it will follow a distorted path.

  • Now try a short-range shot. Adjust the model to 100 degrees from vertical (10 degrees below horizontal) to aim the projectile at the ground. It would land about a millimeter from its intended target, 6.8 meters away.

In summary, long-range firing on a massive station would be very difficult. The error would be different depending on the direction you are facing, the velocity of the projectile, and the size of the station. Nonetheless, a coin toss would appear as it would on Earth, and short-range shots would be very precise. A guided missile would always find its intended target, even with the Coriolis effect.

entry.title: Introduction
entry.content:
Try it!

Diameter=50 ft

Start height=4 ft

Angle=0°

Speed=14 ft/s

Gravity=100%

This article accompanies a computer model that shows motion on a spinning space station. The green link opens the model.

Spinning Space Stations and the Coriolis Effect

No one has ever built a spinning space station before. By spinning a space station like a centrifuge, astronauts could be held to the floor like gravity. What would it be like in such a place?

Objects move differently in a spinning environment due to a phenomena called the Coriolis effect. If you were to toss something in the air, it would not land where you expect it to. The farther around the circle you spin while the tossed object is midair, the more distorted its path will look.

I sought to learn more about life in a spinning environment by building a computer model. Whether or not we should build a spinning space station is up to history to decide; however, it seems likely that someday there will be such an environment, and when it exists, the Coriolis effect will be a major part of life there.

Should We Build a Spinning Space Station?

There are arguments both for and against building a spinning space station.

Creating a spinning environment would be expensive, and it is unclear how well astronauts could adapt to a spinning world. Each direction of motion would produce a different sensation, so the body would need to adapt to each direction differently. The stars on the computer model page are shown spinning slower than reality because it is too easy to get dizzy looking at it (of course, it is the person that is actually spinning, not the stars).

On the other hand, producing gravity may prove essential to counteract the health effects of weightlessness on deep-space missions. Life without gravity causes vision changes, reduced blood volume, a weakened immune system, premature aging, weakened bones and muscles, and more. The result of weightlessness is similar to prolonged bed rest. If future astronauts must spend several years in space traveling to and from Mars, then these health effects will be a problem. One of the main objectives of astronaut Scott Kelly’s recent year-long trip to space was to learn more about these health effects.

I believe that we should build a spinning space station for the purpose of learning more about this type of environment. We cannot know if this environment will be helpful to astronauts if we never try it. When we eventually do build a spinning environment, it will be interesting to learn more about how astronauts adapt to the Coriolis effect.

Can We Get Rid of the Coriolis Effect?

As we increase the size of the spinning space station, the Coriolis effect decreases. However, it would be impossible to build a station large enough to eliminate it. So no, we cannot eliminate the Coriolis effect.

The improvement you see as you increase space station size is logarithmic; you need to increase the size by an order of magnitude to see a small decrease in the Coriolis effect. I have modeled our toss against increasing station size on a logarithmic graph. On Earth, a toss thrown straight up would land exactly at your feet, 0 cm away.

This graph assumes the toss starts at a height of 1.2 meters, goes straight up at 4 m/s, and has 1g of gravity at the floor. This is the default setting for the computer model.

Try the computer model for yourself so you can see how different data points affect a throw.
